text: for me through my career for work has been that I was dissatisfied with something that I did before. And so the first book, although I was happy with it because I felt it was authentic, I knew that I'd written everything that I believed. Maybe I left a few things out, but it was an accurate representation of how I felt about hedging. But chapter eight, which is the final chapter in The Second Lake Down, was sketchy. I didn't really understand central banks as well, how they work. I didn't really understand the various crisis prediction models, what could legitimately be done. And so I didn't really have a foundation for saying, how can we modify standard risk estimates using things that traders, people who are aware of flows, people who are aware of leverage, hopefully incorporate into their assessment of sizing. So I wanted to tell people basically, don't do too much if there are these latent, risks in the market you want to trade that aren't being reflected in the price action of the assets that you're trying to manage. So I felt that that was a necessary book to write because I wanted to triangulate between the more, the very good, but more fanciful book by Rick Bookstaber, The End of Theory, which I thought was excellent, but it didn't, you couldn't really take anything too solid away from it. I wanted to sort of bridge that gap and come up with something that looks a little bit like a standard risk model, but made a generalization of the risks and adjustments in the presence of credit and positioning risk. And so that was the goal of the book. You're right, it's less practical. It's more open-ended. It requires more DIY type thinking where every situation is different. You might miss the relevant situation that could make the big fortune or save your skin. But I felt that such a book had to be written. And when I, at least I wanted to write it, when I heard about mean field theory and so forth, mean field games, I felt that was exactly the right thing to do. And so I wrote it. And I wrote it. And I wrote it. And I wrote it. So what I found interesting to me about, basically, this book was basically the best framework to use, because it gave us at least some hope for coming up with concrete risk estimates
